channel.title: Aggregated News
channel.description: This is an aggregated news feed.

item.title: Perfusion-Based mAb Production at 250 mL Scale Using ATF Technology
item.summary: In this GEN webinar, Vivian Ott, a process intensification specialist, will present data demonstrating how a small-scale mAb perfusion process can yield comparable outcomes to large-scale bioreactors. Attendees will also hear from Repligen’s Béla Brühlmann, who will introduce the benefits of upstream process intensification. The post Perfusion-Based mAb Production at 250 mL Scale Using ATF Technology appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Alzheimer’s Pathology Reversed, Memory Restored with Lithium Compound in Mice
item.summary: Study shows that lithium plays an essential role in normal brain function and can confer resistance to brain aging and Alzheimer’s disease. Findings indicate lithium is depleted in the brain by binding to toxic amyloid plaques, revealing a new way Alzheimer’s may begin. The post Alzheimer’s Pathology Reversed, Memory Restored with Lithium Compound in Mice appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Novel Non-Opioid Analgesic May Offer Hope Amid U.S. Opioid Crisis
item.summary: A non-opioid analgesic, called ADRIANA, targets α2B-adrenoceptors. In early clinical trials, the compound relieved postoperative pain without opioid-related side effects. A U.S. Phase II trial is now planned, offering new hope for pain relief. The post Novel Non-Opioid Analgesic May Offer Hope Amid U.S. Opioid Crisis appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Opinion: Amid the countless tragedies of Gaza, chronic disease remains
item.summary: The psychological burden of chronic disease, especially during displacement, can be as crushing as the physical pain.

item.title: Work on mRNA therapies was surging. Now Kennedy has rocked the field
item.summary: Companies in a burgeoning field of mRNA therapeutics express shock at HHS' deep cuts to research funding.

item.title: As mRNA falls out of favor for HHS, are cancer vaccines next?
item.summary: Cancer vaccines in development rely on mRNA technology under attack by RFK Jr. “I am concerned that this could bleed over,' an oncologist says.

item.title: Opinion: Doctors sometimes fake CPR — and they should
item.summary: If you want to eliminate the half-hearted CPR known as the “slow code,” you have to eliminate the conditions that make them necessary, two bioethicists write.

item.title: Wyden, Warren launch investigation into UnitedHealth’s nursing home practices
item.summary: An investigation by Sens. Ron Wyden and Elizabeth Warren is another setback for UnitedHealth, which recently laid out a lower profit outlook and promised reforms to its operations.

item.title: Alnylam could be the next mega-cap biotech
item.summary: Might Alnylam be the next mega-cap biotech? It has momentum.

item.title: Eli Lilly’s much-anticipated obesity pill yields modest results
item.summary: Eli Lilly has hoped its candidate weight loss pill would safeguard its lead in the obesity market, but new results may prove disappointing.

item.title: Superagers’ brains offer clues to cognitive resilience, and possible treatments, researchers say
item.summary: Some octogenarians have exceptionally sharp memories, even sharper than people who are decades younger. A new analysis of their brains could help explain why.

item.title: Keros shakes up leadership structure to go all in on DMD drug
item.summary: Keros has shaken up its leadership structure as the biotech attempts to shake off the failure of its blood pressure drug by going all in on an early-stage Duchenne muscular dystrophy asset.

item.title: Lilly preps oral GLP-1 for regulatory review after phase 3 shows 12% weight loss
item.summary: As other pharmas drop next-gen obesity assets, Eli Lilly’s experimental oral GLP-1 has prompted weight loss up to an average of 27.3 pounds in the first of two pivotal trials, queuing up plans for a regulatory submission before the end of this year.

item.title: Gilead hands back one Arcus cancer candidate from $725M deal
item.summary: Gilead has returned the rights to a cancer candidate it licensed from Arcus Biosciences in a $725 million, multiprogram deal, confirming its retreat from an asset that was deprioritized earlier this year.

item.title: At HHS, mRNA has fallen out of favor. What’s next?
item.summary: And other health new stories of the day.

item.title: Eli Lilly shakes up pain pipeline as part of quarterly R&D clearout
item.summary: Eli Lilly is pivoting its pain pipeline, punting a midstage program it licensed from Centrexion Therapeutics while adding a candidate from its recent SiteOne Therapeutics buyout to its early-phase portfolio.

item.title: Minghui raises $131M 'pre-IPO' round to bankroll JAK inhibitor launch, ADC trials
item.summary: Minghui has secured $131 million for what the company describes as a “pre-IPO” round to fuel the potential launch of its eye drug in China as well as various clinical-stage oncology and immunology assets.

item.title: Pharmalittle: We’re reading about mRNA cancer vaccines, Lilly’s disappointing obesity pill data, and more
item.summary: Cancer vaccine experts are worried that if the Trump administration takes a hostile posture towards mRNA broadly, cancer therapy may be hindered

item.title: Eli Lilly’s key obesity pill falls short of rivals, but the company still beat on earnings
item.summary: Plus more biotech news of the day, brought to you by The Readout.

item.title: Strand's Big Pharma-backed series B brings in $153M to advance mRNA tumor drugs
item.summary: An impressive array of Big Pharma backers lined up to help ensure Strand Therapeutics has the funding needed to take its mRNA-based solid tumor drug further into the clinic.

item.title: NASA and Google built a health AI tool for astronauts
item.summary: In STAT's Health Tech newsletter: Linda Yaccarino's new job, UnitedHealth data breaches, and NASA's health AI.

item.title: FTC aims to stop Edwards’ acquisition of JenaValve
item.summary: The Federal Trade Commission moved to block Edwards Lifesciences’ purchase of JenaValve Technology and its transcatheter heart valve implant for treating aortic regurgitation, expected to obtain FDA approval this year.

item.title: Wacker and Gearbox Biosciences Join Forces on Plasmid DNA Manufacturing
item.summary: Gearbox Biosciences and Wacker stress that they are both committed to fostering a culture of innovation and collaboration, with the shared goal of advancing the field of biologics manufacturing. The post Wacker and Gearbox Biosciences Join Forces on Plasmid DNA Manufacturing appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Dewpoint Therapeutics, biotech startup in a once-buzzy field, cuts 70% of staff
item.summary: Dewpoint Therapeutics, a startup working in the once-buzzy field of biomolecular condensates, has laid off most of its staff.

item.title: DOJ and UnitedHealth reach settlement on $3.3 billion Amedisys deal
item.summary: The Amedisys deal would add to UnitedHealth's home and hospice-care operations.

item.title: Kennedy’s rejection of mRNA vaccines thwarts scientific progress — and threatens national security, experts say
item.summary: Health secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s decision to discontinue funding for mRNA vaccines has alarmed scientists. But it is also a matter of national security, experts say.

item.title: Asthma Drug Prevents Food-Related Anaphylaxis in Allergic Mice
item.summary: Separate murine studies showed that food-induced anaphylaxis is driven by distinct immune pathways involving inflammatory lipids called leukotrienes, pointing to potential use of the FDA-approved asthma drug, Zileuton, to block this life-threatening allergic response. The post Asthma Drug Prevents Food-Related Anaphylaxis in Allergic Mice appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Investor syndicate takes majority control of HistoSonics
item.summary: A group of more than a dozen international investors have purchased a majority stake in HistoSonics as the company looks to grow its sonic tumor treatment system.

item.title: NIH Foundation Launches Industry-Backed Program to Advance Non-Animal Testing Methods Toward Regulatory Use
item.summary:
The Foundation for the National Institutes of Health (FNIH) has launched the Validation and Qualification Network (VQN), a multi-stakeholder initiative aimed at accelerating the regulatory acceptance of alternatives to animal testing in drug development.
Announced on July 24, the VQN is part of the NIH’s broader Complement Animal Research in Experimentation (Complement-ARIE) program, initiated in 2024 under former U.S. administration. It brings together dozens of partners, including U.S. and European regulators, major pharmaceutical companies like Sanofi, Novo Nordisk, and GSK, as well as CROs such as Charles River Laboratories.

item.title: Recursion Reports Q2 2025 with $7M Sanofi Milestone, Announces Clinical Updates
item.summary: Recursion Pharmaceuticals, a clinical-stage TechBio company headquartered in Salt Lake City, a founding member of BioHive, Utah’s life sciences collective, reported Q2 2025 financials with a net loss of $171.9 million, up from $97.5 million in Q2 2024, citing R&D expansion following its Exscientia merger and Tempus partnership. The company highlighted progress on internal assets REC-1245 (RBM39 degrader) and REC-617 (CDK7 inhibitor), alongside a $7 million milestone payment from Sanofi for a partnered immunology program.

item.title: Unpacking Trump’s approach to health care oversight
item.summary: This is the web edition of D.C. Diagnosis, STAT's twice-weekly newsletter about the politics and policy of health and medicine.

item.title: WVU Cancer Institute Adopts Ryght AI Tools for Trial Matching and Enrollment
item.summary: West Virginia University (WVU) Cancer Institute has joined Ryght AI’s clinical trial site network, giving the academic cancer center access to tools designed to automate site feasibility and trial enrollment workflows. The partnership gives WVU Cancer Institute a position within Ryght’s expanding network of research institutions and contract research organizations using generative and agentic AI to support clinical operations.

item.title: Chai Discovery Raises $70M to Expand Zero-Shot Biologics Design AI Platform
item.summary: Chai Discovery, an AI drug discovery company founded in late 2024 and backed by OpenAI, has raised $70 million in new funding to expand development of its antibody and molecular design platform, Chai-2. The round brings Chai’s valuation to approximately $550 million. Investors include Menlo Ventures, DST Global Partners, Yosemite, SV Angel, Avenir, DCVC, and others. Existing investors OpenAI and Thrive Capital, Dimension, Neo, Lachy Groom, and Fred Ehrsam.

item.title: Closing a zombie biotech, and Lilly’s disappointing obesity readout
item.summary: This week on 'The Readout LOUD' podcast: closing a zombie biotech and Lilly's disappointing obesity readout.

item.title: 10x Genomics Scales Up, Agrees to Acquire Scale Biosciences
item.summary: 10x Genomics is acquiring Scale Biosciences, with a plan to integrate the technology into the Chromium portfolio. In this exclusive, Serge Saxonov of 10X Genomics and Giovanna Prout of Scale Biosciences discuss what the acquisition means for single cell genomics. The post 10x Genomics Scales Up, Agrees to Acquire Scale Biosciences appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Computational Models Forecast C. diff Infections Before They Develop
item.summary: Personalized computational models predict C. diff colonization risk and evaluate targeted probiotic treatments, a new study finds. The post Computational Models Forecast <i>C. diff</i> Infections Before They Develop appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Claiming to fight waste, Trump administration slashes potentially cost-saving research
item.summary: Claiming it wants to cut waste, the Trump administration has terminated grants for research testing ways to save the health care system money.

item.title: How a Colorado dietitian became Instagram’s top MAHA critic
item.summary: Jessica Knurick is one of Instagram's fiercest MAHA critics — and with a Ph.D in nutrition science, she's dedicated to debunking misinformation.

item.title: Trump administration wants to defund watchdog groups for Navajo mental health
item.summary: Proposed HHS budget cuts would reduce funding of protection and advocacy programs for individuals with mental illness.

item.title: Opinion: A ‘tropical’ disease is spreading in American wildlife
item.summary: This neglected tropical disease is no longer confined to the tropics. It’s here, in the United States, spreading silently in wildlife.

item.title: Alzheimer’s Therapy Delivery Boosted with Engineered Antibody
item.summary: To address efficacy and safety limitations of current Alzheimer's antibody therapeutics, researchers explored receptor-mediated transport across the BBB. This strategy utilizes native transport proteins to convey the therapeutics between the vascular system and brain. The post Alzheimer’s Therapy Delivery Boosted with Engineered Antibody appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Bicycle lays off 25% of workforce as Genentech rides away from R&D pact
item.summary: Bicycle Therapeutics is reducing its head count by around 25% to extend its cash runway into 2028. The layoffs, which are part of a push to cut spending by 30%, follow Genentech’s termination of an oncology collaboration with the biotech.

item.title: Chutes & Ladders—Altos ascends with new clinical leader
item.summary: Longevity company Altos Labs has secured a new clinical leader from the eye of the storm. Former Tornado Therapeutics co-founder and CEO Joan Mannick, Ph.D., is now senior vice president, chief medical officer and head of product development at the Bay Area biotech.

item.summary: When you think of biotech hubs, the first image that comes to mind may be the sleek waterfront offices of Boston Seaport or the scenic hills of San Francisco’s Bay Area.

item.title: XtalPi And DoveTree Finalize $6B AI Drug Discovery Agreement
item.summary: XtalPi has signed a definitive agreement with DoveTree Medicines for an AI- and robotics-powered drug discovery collaboration valued at up to $5.99 billion. The deal builds on the companies’ June 2025 letter of intent and formalizes one of the largest reported financial commitments to AI-enabled pharmaceutical R&D.

item.title: Apreo Health nets $130M to develop lung scaffold for emphysema
item.summary: After emerging from stealth earlier this year, Apreo Health has raised $130 million to breathe new life into the development of COPD implants.

item.title: Gilead culls Novo-partnered MASH candidate and 2 cancer assets
item.summary: After the recent approval and launch of twice-yearly HIV prophylactic Yeztugo, Gilead is cleaning up its R&D pipeline. The Bay Area company has dropped two early-stage cancer candidates and a Novo Nordisk-partnered combination treatment for metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH).

item.title: Advocates urge South Africa to reopen antitrust probe into Vertex Pharmaceuticals
item.summary: Patient advocacy groups are urging the South African government to reopen an antitrust investigation into Vertex Pharmaceuticals.

item.title: Trump executive order seeks to centralize control of grantmaking under political appointees
item.summary: A sweeping new executive order seeks to transform how the federal government awards billions of dollars in research grants

item.title: Reversing Parkinson’s in Mice, Protecting Primates from HIV, Top 10 Biotech Clusters, and Sarepta
item.summary: In this episode of GEN's Touching Base, we discuss the impacts of low oxygen on Parkinson’s disease, HIV protection for newborn primates via gene therapy, impacts of GLP-1 on muscle strength, this year’s GEN A-List of Top 10 Biopharma Clusters, and updates on Sarepta Therapeutics. The post Reversing Parkinson’s in Mice, Protecting Primates from HIV, Top 10 Biotech Clusters, and Sarepta appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: 10x Genomics scoops up Scale Biosciences and its single-cell analysis kits

item.title: Conserved T-Cell Targets May Boost Universal Coronavirus Vaccine Development
item.summary: A new vaccine design pipeline could protect against emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants, and other coronaviruses, by pinpointing conserved epitopes across different respiratory viruses that are broadly recognized by T cells. The post Conserved T-Cell Targets May Boost Universal Coronavirus Vaccine Development appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Self-Assembling Nanoparticles at Room Temp Could Transform Drug Delivery
item.summary: A research team focused on making a delivery system without complicated microfluidics that could work for RNA and protein therapies, because right now, most platforms are specialized for just one. The post Self-Assembling Nanoparticles at Room Temp Could Transform Drug Delivery appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: T7-ORACLE Foretells Functional Proteins by Accelerating Evolution
item.summary: While traditional methods for directed evolution require time consuming rounds of DNA manipulation and testing, T7-ORACLE is a synthetic biology platform that accelerates evolution to engineer proteins for broad therapeutic applications. The post T7-ORACLE Foretells Functional Proteins by Accelerating Evolution appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: CRISPR Screen Uncovers How Macrophages Respond to Pathogens
item.summary: Scientists reported a time-resolved analysis of molecular processes that unfold when macrophages respond to specific pathogens and infection-linked stimuli, identifying a network of regulators that share the responsibility of triggering the most appropriate immune response. The post CRISPR Screen Uncovers How Macrophages Respond to Pathogens appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.summary: The FDA has denied Stealth BioTherapeutics’ request to reconsider its complete response letter, leaving the fate of the biotech and its investigational treatment for an ultrarare genetic disease hanging in limbo.

item.summary: IO Biotech’s cancer vaccine has “narrowly” failed to beat Keytruda in a phase 3 melanoma trial, but the company remains hopeful of a path to approval.

item.title: Strand Therapeutics Secures $153 Million for Programmable mRNA Cancer Therapies
item.summary: Strand Therapeutics has closed a $153 million Series B financing led by Swedish investment firm Kinnevik, joined by Regeneron Ventures, ICONIQ, Amgen Ventures, Alderline Group, JIC-VGI, LG Technology Ventures, and Gradiant Corporation. Existing investors FPV Ventures, Playground Global, Eli Lilly, ANRI, and Potentum also participated. The round brings the company’s total funding to over $250 million and an estimated valuation of $550 million, up from $359 million in late 2024, according to PitchBook. Kinnevik’s Ala Alenazi, Ph.D., will join Strand’s board of directors.

item.title: From Data to Discovery: How BenchSci’s ASCEND Builds a Map for Biomedical Reasoning
item.summary: Scientific knowledge is expanding faster than at any point in human history, with PubMed indexing over 1.3 million new biomedical articles annually. In parallel, organizations implementing lab automation are generating experimental data at scale.

item.title: Research details new AI-enhanced 3D ultrasound imaging method
item.summary: A research team from Pusan National University has developed a novel deep learning model coined Moglo-Net, designed to enable three-dimensional reconstruction of images from hand-held ultrasound procedures.

item.title: Sartorius Stedim Biotech and Nanotein Technologies Partner to Boost Cell Therapy Manufacturing
item.summary: Sartorius Stedim Biotech will offer Nanotein Technologies’ lead products to customers around the globe, including the NanoSpark STEM-T Soluble T Cell Activator and NanoSpark GROW-NK Soluble Activator. The post Sartorius Stedim Biotech and Nanotein Technologies Partner to Boost Cell Therapy Manufacturing appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Expedition inks $645M pact to pocket Fosun’s lung disease asset in knapsack

item.title: SetPoint serves up $140M fundraising after FDA approves its implant for rheumatoid arthritis
item.summary: Shortly after obtaining an FDA green light, SetPoint announced $140 million in new funding to juice the commercialization of its neuromodulation implant for rheumatoid arthritis.

item.title: Aging-Focused BioAge Posts Q2 2025 Results: Advances Metabolic Pipeline and Expands Longevity Data Platform
item.summary: BioAge Labs reported second-quarter 2025 results alongside updates on its metabolic disease pipeline and human aging data platform. The company is advancing its oral NLRP3 inhibitor toward Phase 1 testing in 2025, expanding its APJ agonist portfolio, and initiating large-scale molecular profiling through the HUNT Biobank. The update follows earlier developments including a multi-year Novartis collaboration worth up to $530 million.

item.title: Rat Brain Reveals Code for Learned Skills, Clues into Human Movement Disorders
item.summary: The rat basal ganglia is shown to implement two different codes, one for learned movements and another for innate behaviors. The new study offers insight into human movement disorders, such as Parkinson’s, Huntington's, and Tourette Syndrome. The post Rat Brain Reveals Code for Learned Skills, Clues into Human Movement Disorders appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.summary: Low cost “ring-insert” technology allows the long-term culture and imaging of nerve cells directly in brain tissue, offering a new platform for drug testing, live-cell microscopy, and disease research. item.title: Novel RNA biotech winds down after missing milestone in Bayer pact
item.summary: Another Massachusetts biotech has reached the end of the road. NextRNA Therapeutics has begun winding down operations with a “heavy heart,” the company’s co-founder, president and CEO Dominique Verhelle, Ph.D., announced in an Aug. 9 LinkedIn post.

item.title: Mitochondria-Targeted Receptor Counters Neurodegeneration in Mice
item.summary: A mitochondria-targeted receptor, called mitoDREADD-Gs, has been developed, which improves memory in Alzheimer’s and frontotemporal dementia mouse models—establishing a causal link between mitochondrial dysfunction and neurodegenerative cognitive decline. The post Mitochondria-Targeted Receptor Counters Neurodegeneration in Mice appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.summary: The inclusion of pregnant participants in RCTs has remained flat over the past 15 years. Changing this norm will require institutional-level reforms.

item.summary: “If we don’t act now, we’ll lose one of the most efficient, cost-effective access points in the U.S. health care system,” writes Walgreens’ chief pharmacy officer.

item.title: Abridge adds live prior authorization to its AI scribe with Highmark Health
item.summary: Ambient scribe company Abridge, partnering with Highmark Health, says it can give information on prior authorization during, not just after, a patient visit.

item.title: Vaxart seeks answers as BARDA funding for stop-start vaccine project dries up again
item.summary: Vaxart is actively seeking more information about why it was told to stop work under a federally funded COVID-19 vaccine contract.

item.summary: Bayer has teamed up with Kumquat Biosciences for a juicy opportunity, committing up to $1.3 billion for the global license to a KRAS G12D inhibitor that is on the cusp of the clinic.

item.title: Novartis' blood disorder readout earns Novartis 3rd phase 3 win for ianalumab this week
item.summary: A day after posting a pair of phase 3 wins for the tricky indication of Sjögren's syndrome, the Swiss pharma has unveiled a separate late-stage victory in another B-cell-driven autoimmune disease.

item.title: Tahoe Therapeutics Raises $30 Million to Expand Single-Cell Data Production for AI Models
item.summary:
Tahoe Therapeutics has raised $30 million in Series A financing, increasing total funding to $42 million and valuing the Palo Alto-based company at $120 million.
The round was led by Amplify Partners, with Databricks Ventures, Wing Venture Capital, General Catalyst, AIX Ventures, Mubadala Ventures, Civilization Ventures, and Conviction. Capital will be used to scale the company’s Mosaic platform, designed to generate large-scale single-cell datasets for training AI models in oncology drug discovery.

item.title: Boston’s lab building boom has gone bust. What can be done with the empty space?
item.summary: Nearly 36% of lab space in the Boston area is now empty.

item.summary: Using its hub-and-spoke business model, PureTech is launching a new subsidiary, Celea Therapeutics, to develop its promising candidate for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and other fibrotic and inflammatory lung conditions.

item.title: How Organoids Are Revolutionizing Neuroscience Research
item.summary: On this episode of GEN Live, we’ll discuss how organoids are advancing research with a particular focus on neural organoids. The post How Organoids Are Revolutionizing Neuroscience Research appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Surging Demand Reshaping Vector Manufacturing
item.summary: Soaring global demand for vectors has seen suppliers reach for innovative purification methods, such as affinity-based capture and dual chromatography, to enhance product quality and improve throughput. item.title: Breaking the Link Between Alcohol Use and Pancreatic Cancer

item.summary: Asimov will lead a project under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services’ Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) Biopharmaceutical Manufacturing Preparedness Consortium (BioMaP-Consortium), part of the Administration for Strategic Preparedness and Response (ASPR). The initiative is funded at up to $8.49 million over three years and focuses on manufacturing optimization for a monoclonal antibody (mAb) cocktail designed to treat filovirus disease caused by Ebola virus (EBOV) and Sudan virus (SUDV).

item.title: Vedanta’s live bacteria cocktail fails to reduce ulcerative colitis severity in ph. 2 trial
item.summary: Vedanta Biosciences’ dreams of using live bacteria to treat inflammatory bowel disease have been dashed. The Massachusetts-based microbiome outfit’s mixture of 16 bacterial strains failed to reduce disease severity in the colons of patients with ulcerative colitis, Vedanta said on Wednesday.

item.title: PolarisQB Launches Quantum-AI Drug Discovery Platform for Beta Testing
item.summary: Polaris Quantum Biotech (PolarisQB) has launched QuADD (Quantum-Aided Drug Design), a SaaS platform combining quantum computing and AI for early-stage drug discovery. The company is opening a beta program for researchers and companies to access the system, which is designed to drastically reduce lead discovery timelines by computationally navigating chemical spaces of up to 10^30 molecules.

item.title: Gameto Gets $44M to Complete U.S. Phase 3 Trial of Stem Cell-Derived Ex Vivo Egg Maturation Therapy

The financing supports the company’s Phase 3 trial of Fertilo, an iPSC-derived therapy that matures eggs ex vivo for IVF, and the expansion of its reproductive health pipeline.

item.title: Doximity Buys Pathway Medical for $63M, Expands AI Suite for Physicians

The purchase includes $26 million in cash and up to $37 million in equity grants, closing on July 29, 2025. The acquisition follows the company’s release of free AI-powered tools for verified U.S. physicians, including its recently launched Doximity Scribe.

The decision follows the product’s earlier Breakthrough Device Designation and allows its use as a regulated medical device in qualified pathology laboratories.

item.title: Lantern Pharma Reports on Q2: Clinical Trials & New AI Prediction Tools
item.summary: Dallas-based Lantern Pharma reported Q2 2025 results, marking progress across its oncology pipeline and AI drug development platform. The company completed Phase 1a enrollment for LP-184 in 65 patients with solid tumors, set the maximum tolerated and recommended Phase 2 doses, and is preparing Phase 1b/2 studies in recurrent triple-negative breast cancer and bladder cancer. LP-284 recorded its first complete metabolic response in a refractory lymphoma patient, and LP-300 continued to show clinical activity in the HARMONIC trial for advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

item.title: Schrödinger Ends CDC7 Inhibitor Program Following Two Patient Deaths in AML Trial
item.summary: Schrödinger, founded in 1990 and known for its physics-based computational platform used in drug and materials discovery, has halted development of its experimental CDC7 inhibitor SGR-2921 after the drug was linked to two patient deaths in a phase 1 trial for relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and high-risk myelodysplastic syndromes. The decision removes a candidate the company had once described as the most potent CDC7 inhibitor reported, while it continues advancing other oncology, immunology, and neurology programs in early-stage development.

item.title: Texas declares its measles outbreak over
item.summary: The Texas measles outbreak that sickened 762 people since late January is over, state health officials said Monday.

item.title: Eli Lilly Signs $1.3 Billion AI Drug Discovery Deal with Superluminal
item.summary: Eli Lilly has entered into a collaboration with Boston-based Superluminal Medicines valued at up to $1.3 billion to discover small-molecule drugs for obesity and cardiometabolic diseases. The agreement gives Lilly exclusive rights to develop and commercialize compounds identified through Superluminal’s drug discovery platform, with Superluminal receiving upfront and milestone payments, an equity investment, and tiered royalties on sales.

item.title: Private equity firm acquires clinical trial site network Headlands Research
item.summary: After years of striking acquisitions to build up its site network, Headlands Research has now been bought itself. Headlands has been scooped up by private equity firm THL Partners, which entered an agreement to buy the clinical trial company from founding firm KKR.

item.title: Genentech scraps $2B deal with cell therapy biotech
item.summary: Genentech’s summer of downsizing and cost-cutting continued this morning, with the Roche subsidiary announcing the termination of a cell therapy deal worth as much as $2 billion. The pact with Adaptive Biotechnologies, originally launched in January 2019, was meant to see Genentech develop personalized cancer medicines based on Adaptive’s T cell receptor (TCR) tech.

item.title: AI Drug Developer Insilico Medicine Readies Brain-Penetrant Therapy For Parkinson’s Trials
item.summary: Insilico Medicine reports it has finished IND-enabling work for ISM8969, an oral, blood-brain-barrier-penetrant NLRP3 inhibitor and aims to file an IND in Q4 2025 to start clinical evaluation in Parkinson’s disease. In preclinical MPTP models, the candidate reportedly produced dose-dependent motor gains (with significant effects at 20 mg/kg) with a supportive PK/PD package. Full datasets are not yet public.

item.title: Industry Partnerships with Iowa State University to Support New Scale-Up Facility
item.summary: BioMADE’s investment in the state of Iowa is expected to provide both Iowa startups and companies access to the technology infrastructure required to determine if a product is commercially viable. The post Industry Partnerships with Iowa State University to Support New Scale-Up Facility appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Space Station Stem Cells Successfully Produce Healthy Mice
item.summary: Mouse stem cells cryopreserved on the ISS for six months produced healthy offspring. The study not only illustrates that germ cells retain fertility in space, but also informs future long-duration space missions. The post Space Station Stem Cells Successfully Produce Healthy Mice appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Brain Abnormalities in Children Tied to Prenatal Pesticide Exposure
item.summary: Researchers reported enduring and widespread molecular, cellular, and metabolic effects in the brain, as well as progressively poorer fine motor control in youth exposed prenatally to the insecticide chlorpyrifos. The post Brain Abnormalities in Children Tied to Prenatal Pesticide Exposure appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: New blood pressure treatment guidelines add recommendations for renal denervation
item.summary: The American Heart Association and the American College of Cardiology updated their 2017 hypertension guidelines, including renal denervation for the first time.

item.title: Shankar Ramaswamy’s gene therapy biotech raises $313M
item.summary: Gene therapy biotech Kriya Therapeutics has secured $313 million in a new series fundraise.

item.title: Kriya Raises $313 Million to Advance Gene Therapy Programs
item.summary:
Kriya Therapeutics has secured $313.3 million in new financing, according to a recent SEC filing. The filing did not outline neither the planned use of the funds, nor the names of the investors, specifying only that two parties contributed.
The North Carolina– and California-based company is developing single-dose gene therapies across ophthalmology, neurology, and metabolic diseases. Its pipeline includes treatments for geographic atrophy, thyroid eye disease, trigeminal neuralgia, focal epilepsy, type 1 diabetes, and metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH).

item.title: National pediatrics group splits with RFK Jr. on Covid vaccinations
item.summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics is splitting from the federal government in its recommendations on which children should receive the Covid-19 vaccine.

item.title: Opinion: The hidden neurological toll of wildfires
item.summary: Disaster response systems are woefully unprepared to address long-term neurological health impacts.

item.title: Why direct-to-consumer sales are unlikely to significantly lower drug costs
item.summary: With Trump's backing, the pharma industry is leaning into the idea of more 'direct-to-consumer' sales. But experts say the model is unlikely to significantly lower drug costs.

item.title: Trump may push hard for lower drug prices using a tool created by Democrats
item.summary: WASHINGTON — President Trump may aggressively negotiate lower drug prices in Medicare using a program that Democrats created and Trump rarely mentions in public.  Since his first term, Trump has…

item.title: Opinion: Study saying monthly cash won’t help children’s health is highly misleading — even irresponsible
item.summary: “The lack of findings thus far in the Baby’s First Years study should not be used to justify actions that will further hurt children’s developmental health,” two experts write.

item.title: Can a humble, Harley-riding professor and former Trump adviser fend off science cuts?
item.summary: Kelvin Droegemeier, a Trump adviser in his first term, is leading an effort to offer an alternative to the administration’s plan for reshaping federal research funding

item.title: Viking Therapeutics oral weight loss drug hits mark in mid-stage trial but disappoints investors
item.summary: A new oral weight loss drug developed by Viking Therapeutics hit the mark in a mid-stage clinical trial, but the side effect and discontinuation rates disappointed investors.

item.title: Early data on over-the-counter birth control
item.summary: Plus other health news stories of the day.

item.title: China's RemeGen sells Asia rights to VEGF/FGF eye drug in $180M deal
item.summary: China’s RemeGen has sold certain Asia rights to its phase 3-stage eye disease drug to Japan’s Santen Pharmaceutical for 250 million Chinese yuan ($34.8 million) upfront.

item.title: VantAI plays matchmaker for Halda's 'hold-and-kill' drugs in $1B deal
item.summary: Halda Therapeutics has struck a deal with VantAI, entering into a pact that could be worth more than $1 billion to secure a source of targets for its novel approach to oncology and immunology.

item.title: CSL to lay off up to 15% of workforce, cut R&D costs and spin out vaccine unit
item.summary: CSL is laying off up to 15% of its workforce as the company looks to cut R&D costs and spin out its vaccine subsidiary.

item.title: Opthea, still reeling from eye disease flops, ramps up cuts to 85% of staff and loses CEO
item.summary: Opthea’s options may be shrinking as the eye disease biotech comes to terms with a pair of phase 3 failures, but the company isn’t quite ready to give up.

item.title: Owkin to Bring Agentic AI into Vienna’s Oncology Ecosystem
item.summary: Owkin and the Comprehensive Cancer Center of the Medical University of Vienna have entered a collaboration to deploy agentic AI tools in oncology research and care. The partnership will introduce Owkin’s AI copilot, Owkin K, into Vienna’s oncology ecosystem, with a first focus on advanced bladder cancer. The system will be refined through feedback from clinicians and researchers, aiming to support biological reasoning, precision medicine, and therapeutic strategy development.

item.title: VantAI, Halda Therapeutics Launch $1B+ Proximity-Based Therapy Collaboration
item.summary: VantAI will leverage its Neo-1 foundation model to identify and validate novel, context-specific target-effector pairs to feed into Halda’s proximity-based therapy development pipeline for cancer and immunology indications. The post VantAI, Halda Therapeutics Launch $1B+ Proximity-Based Therapy Collaboration appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Pharmalittle: We’re reading about conflicts on U.S. vaccine panels, pharma DTC sales, and much more
item.summary: Conflicts of interest on federal government vaccine panels have declined to “historically low levels” in recent years

item.title: FDA delays decision on Regenxbio gene therapy
item.summary: And more biotech news brought to you by The Readout.

item.title: Generative AI Designs Novel Antibiotics Against MRSA and Drug-Resistant Gonorrhea
item.summary: Researchers at MIT and the Broad Institute have reported generative artificial intelligence systems capable of designing entirely new antibiotics, including a compound active against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The study, published August 14 in Cell, describes two lead molecules—NG1 and DN1—produced by deep learning models trained on a dataset of ~40,000 small molecules with known antibacterial profiles.

item.title: Viking hits stormy seas as phase 2 oral obesity data sink stock
item.summary: Viking Therapeutics has reported phase 2 data on its oral obesity drug candidate, linking the peptide to weight loss of up to 12.2% after 13 weeks. But with 38% of patients discontinuing treatment at the most effective dose, investors sent the stock down 37% in premarket trading.

item.title: BioAge Labs Begins Phase 1 Trial of Oral NLRP3 Inhibitor for Obesity
item.summary: BioAge Labs has started human testing of BGE-102, an orally available NLRP3 inhibitor designed to cross the blood-brain barrier. The Phase 1 trial will evaluate safety, dosing, and biological activity, with early results expected by the end of 2025. The compound is initially being developed for obesity, after showing weight-loss effects in preclinical studies both alone and in combination with GLP-1 receptor agonists.

item.title: How Trump may use Democrats’ drug-price negotiation law
item.summary: This is the web edition of D.C. Diagnosis, STAT's twice-weekly newsletter about the politics and policy of health and medicine.

item.title: FDA pushes back PDUFA date for Regenxbio's Hunter syndrome gene therapy
item.summary: Delays from the Food and Drug Administration continue to pile up, with Maryland-based Regenxbio the latest to report the review of one of its assets has been extended.

item.title: FDA rejection derails PTC Therapeutics' rare disease hopeful
item.summary: Despite missing its primary endpoint in a phase 3 study, PTC had held out hope that another endpoint would help its candidate pass muster with the FDA.

item.title: Elevance loses lawsuit over Medicare Advantage quality ratings
item.summary: A federal judge rejected Elevance's argument that the government unfair lowered its ratings.

item.title: TGA casts a baleful glance at medical scribes
item.summary: Australia’s Therapeutic Goods Administration recently reported that it has concerns about the use of digital scribes, stating that any such software that analyzes or interprets clinical conversations may qualify as a regulated medical product.

item.title: Medtronic expands board to chase M&A, efficiencies as activist investor takes stake
item.summary: The company’s newest stakeholder, Elliott Investment Management, said it has become one of Medtronic's largest investors.

item.title: Nighttime insulin patch pump maker Luna Diabetes raises $23.6M
item.summary: Luna Diabetes aims to overcome the limitations of insulin pens and multiple daily injections, by offering an overnight patch pump that people can wear while they sleep.

item.title: Ischemia Drives Breast Cancer Growth in Mice by Weakening Immunity
item.summary: A breast cancer study in mice showed that cutting off blood flow in one limb can prematurely age the bone marrow, weakening the immune system’s ability to fight cancer and doubling the rate of tumor growth. The post Ischemia Drives Breast Cancer Growth in Mice by Weakening Immunity appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Particle Measuring Systems Opens New Manufacturing and Contamination Control Innovation Hub
item.summary: PMS says the new facility was designed for innovation and scalability. From expanded production lines to integrated project labs, every element supports faster innovation cycles, adds a company spokesperson. The post Particle Measuring Systems Opens New Manufacturing and Contamination Control Innovation Hub appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Silicon Valley’s Molecular Devices Brings AI to Brain Organoid Culture
item.summary: Molecular Devices has released an upgrade to its CellXpress.ai Automated Cell Culture System, adding rocking incubation and AI-driven workflow automation for brain organoid culture. The feature is designed to reduce the high manual workload of organoid maintenance and to support long-term, reproducible experiments for neurodegenerative disease research.

item.title: In a new era, glucose sensors straddle the line between medical device and wellness tool
item.summary: In a new era, blood glucose sensors are straddling the line between medical device and wellness tool.

item.title: Opinion: AI should come with green, yellow, and red lights for mental health
item.summary: There is an immediate need for a new, agile process that helps everyday people find safe and trustworthy mental health AI support without stifling innovation.

item.summary: Like any conscientious health policy Ph.D. student, Paige Nong went to the doctor for her free annual well visit. But as she checked in, the person at the front desk…

item.title: How AI scribes could usher in higher medical bills
item.summary: In a new episode of the video series STATus Report, we explore how AI scribes could lead to higher medical bills for patients.

item.title: Opinion: Republicans and Democrats must agree: Americans deserve price transparency in health care
item.summary: Sen. Roger Marshall, a Republican and M.D., explains why he and Democratic Sen. John Hickenlooper came together to sponsor health care transparency legislation.

item.title: GLP-1s, cancer care are driving higher employer health care costs in 2026
item.summary: Health care costs are set to jump again next year, creating a challenge for employers.

item.title: Celldex ends esophageal program despite hitting primary endpoint in phase 2 trial
item.summary: Celldex has stopped development of barzolvolimab in eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) despite meeting its primary endpoint in a phase 2 study. The biotech showed the candidate depletes mast cells in the gastrointestinal tract, but that positive finding was overshadowed by the antibody's failure to improve clinical outcomes.

item.title: Former FDA head Stephen Hahn joins radiopharmaceuticals startup as CEO
item.summary: Former FDA commissioner Stephen Hahn is taking the top spot at radiopharmaceuticals startup.

item.title: Generative AI comes up with novel antibiotic structures
item.summary: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed a generative AI model that was able to generate novel antibiotic structures from either chemical fragments or de novo, starting from ammonia, methane, water or no starting point at all. In a study that was published online in Cell, the team tested two dozen of more than 10 million structures that were proposed as potential antibiotics by the model.

item.title: Epithelial Cells Sense Tissue Curvature for Wound Healing
item.summary: The endoplasmic reticulum senses the curvature of tissue gaps by changing its structure, becoming tubular in shape when the surface is convex and flattening into sheet-like structures when the surface is concave, offering applications for wound healing. The post Epithelial Cells Sense Tissue Curvature for Wound Healing appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.summary: GEN reports from the Bioprocessing Summit in Boston where Sanofi's Cenk Undey, PhD, challenged the audience to look “beyond digital.' The post Harnessing Data and AI to Revolutionize Bioprocessing Beyond Digital appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: What updated thresholds for statin use could mean for patients
item.summary: A new heart risk model had raised questions about who should take statins. A new study to 'right-size' yields a similar answer to the old model.

item.title: FDA clears Signos’ over-the-counter, CGM-powered weight loss app
item.summary: Signos' system employs Dexcom's Stelo CGM and pairs it with an app to track how food choices, activity, stress and sleep can all affect metabolism.

item.title: FDA draft recommends overall survival data collection for all cancer trials
item.summary: More than two years after the Food and Drug Administration held a public workshop on measuring overall survival in cancer clinical trials, the agency has released a draft guidance on the topic recommending that OS be used as a primary endpoint whenever feasible.

item.title: Rocket launches from FDA hold, but uncertainty about the biotech’s cash runway looms
item.summary: The FDA has freed Rocket Pharmaceuticals from a clinical hold, giving the gene therapy developer permission to take flight with its pivotal metabolic disorder trial.

item.title: Xoma adds fading Mural Oncology to portfolio of struggling biotechs
item.summary: Xoma Royalty is ravenous for biotechs, and the Bay Area licensing aggregator has found its next meal in Mural Oncology. Xoma is set to acquire Mural for $2.035 per share, for a total value of about $36 million, the company announced on Aug. 20.

item.title: Mapping Out the “Everything” of Protein Secretion
item.summary: If you want to understand, engineer, and control a complex system, you've got to have a parts list, a wiring diagram, and tools to analyze and engineer that system. The post Mapping Out the “Everything” of Protein Secretion appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Is Bioprinting in Bioprocessing’s Future?
item.summary: Bioprinting is very unlikely to replace biopharmaceuticals anytime soon. In the future, though, treating a failing organ through biopharmaceuticals might give way to a transplant with a bioprinted substitute. The post Is Bioprinting in Bioprocessing’s Future? appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Digital Twins Cut COGs and Help Biopharma Reach New Markets
item.summary: Industry engineers use digital twins to assess the impact of varying inputs and conditions on processes, with the aim being to optimize yields, reduce waste, and, ultimately, lower the cost-of-goods. The post Digital Twins Cut COGs and Help Biopharma Reach New Markets appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Continuous Biomanufacturing Is Ready for a Broader Range of Commercial Use
item.summary: The challenges of implementing continuous manufacturing can be minimized with cross-functional technology integration teams; digital integration to improve traceability; regulatory alignment to deal with methodology differences; and supply chain partnerships to improve delivery coordination. The post Continuous Biomanufacturing Is Ready for a Broader Range of Commercial Use appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: After a ‘complete standstill,’ private biotech market reaches new normal, investor says
item.summary: The first half of 2025 was brutal for biotech, but investors are still keen on therapeutics in several indications and silver linings exist, particularly for private companies.

item.title: Ginkgo, Inductive Bio, and Tangible Scientific Connect AI Models with Automated Labs for Drug Discovery
item.summary: Ginkgo Bioworks’ Datapoints unit, Inductive Bio, and Tangible Scientific have partnered to deliver a lab-in-the-loop workflow that ties AI-driven molecular design directly to experimental validation. The collaboration integrates predictive ADMET modeling, automated compound logistics, and rapid assay services, with the aim of reducing cycle times in small molecule drug discovery.

item.title: Iantrek sees $42M fundraising for alternative glaucoma surgery launch
item.summary: Iantrek’s AlloFlo Uveo system is designed to offer ophthalmic surgeons another route to drain fluids from the eye, using a porous, biologic material.

item.title: Enhanced 2D Purification Strategies for Manufacturing Oligonucleotide Therapeutics
item.summary: In this GEN webinar, Joe Guiles, PhD, will describe an enhanced two-step oligonucleotide purification process using strong anion exchange with ion-pair reversed-phase (AX-IPRP) chromatography. The post Enhanced 2D Purification Strategies for Manufacturing Oligonucleotide Therapeutics appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.summary: Epic’s AI overhaul promises to address EHR headaches for clinicians and patients

item.title: IQVIA and Veeva go from adversaries to friends, ending legal spat and forming long-term pact
item.summary: The years-long legal kerfuffle between IQVIA and Veeva Systems has come to a close, with the former adversaries setting aside their differences to launch a series of clinical and commercial partnerships.

item.title: Partners Agree to Deploy AI-Driven Lab-in-the-Loop Workflows Across the Biopharma Industry
item.summary: Datapoints' ADME profiling service delivers high-quality readouts, including microsomal stability, kinetic solubility, P450 inhibition, and permeability, with optional in vitro toxicity readouts on both lead candidates and library-scale compound sets. The post Partners Agree to Deploy AI-Driven Lab-in-the-Loop Workflows Across the Biopharma Industry appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Autism Symptoms Reversed in Mice Using Epilepsy Drug Candidate
item.summary: A preclinical study found that hyperactivity in the reticular thalamic nucleus may drive behaviors commonly associated with autism spectrum disorders and found that autism symptoms in a mouse model were reversed on treatment with an epilepsy drug candidate. The post Autism Symptoms Reversed in Mice Using Epilepsy Drug Candidate appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.summary: Flexible gene expression activity lets a subset of thymus cells take on the identity of different cells types to train the immune system and repair damaged tissue. The post Epigenetic Noise Helps Cells Adopt New Identities to Train the Immune System appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: IV Therapies Transformed into Injections with a Novel Spray Drying Platform
item.summary: A new spray-drying method uses a polyacrylamide copolymer (MoNi) to enable high-dose protein drugs—that typically require IV infusion—to be delivered as injections. This advance may replace lengthy IV infusions and expand access to biologic therapies. The post IV Therapies Transformed into Injections with a Novel Spray Drying Platform appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Brain Organoid Growth Accelerated by Graphene Method Models Age-Related Disease
item.summary: Graphene-Mediated Optical Stimulation (GraMOS) is a safe and non-genetic approach to stimulate neural activity over days to weeks. The method accelerates brain organoid development to model neurodegenerative disorders, such as Alzheimer’s disease. The post Brain Organoid Growth Accelerated by Graphene Method Models Age-Related Disease appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Opinion: Congress must continue to support the VA’s research into psychedelics for PTSD
item.summary: Two members of Congress and a veteran agree: The VA needs to keep up the momentum on psychedelics research.

item.title: As Sarepta Therapeutics fights for Duchenne therapy, a group of patients gets left behind
item.summary: After deaths and FDA setbacks, Sarepta abandoned LGMD gene therapy, leaving families desperate and patients without long-promised treatments.

item.title: Opinion: The trauma of illness can last long after the body has healed
item.summary: “The body can heal while the self remains disconnected”: a psychologist on the overlooked trauma of illness.

item.title: Brain map does not change following amputation, new study finds, upending assumptions
item.summary: Neuroscientists have long held that the brain reorganizes itself when a body part is amputated. A new study says that’s not the case.

item.title: FDA ‘uncertainty’ forces Krystal Biotech to shutter cancer drug trial
item.summary: The FDA's controversial rejection of a skin cancer therapy from Replimune Group has prompted Krystal Biotech to shut down of a clinical trial involving a similar drug.

item.title: Soleno Therapeutics responds to short seller’s Prader-Willi drug safety claims
item.summary: Soleno Therapeutics CEO responds to a 415-page short-seller report alleging safety issues tied to the company's newly approved therapy.

item.title: How AI Is Transforming Medicinal Chemistry Between Discovery and Manufacture
item.summary: In medicinal chemistry, the “make” stage of the design–make–test–analyze (DMTA) cycle is often where good ideas go to die. Synthetic bottlenecks, expensive building blocks, low-yield reactions, and complications during scale-up for manufacturing can turn promising drug candidates into abandoned projects.

item.title: CDC advisory panel member no longer trusts CDC
item.summary: Good morning. We've got a meaty issue for you today. In particular, I urge you to spend some time with Jason Mast's story. It's another heartbreaking chapter of the Sarepta…

item.title: Dynavax's shingles vaccine holds its own against GSK's Shingrix in early clinical test
item.summary: Dynavax’s lofty ambition to snatch Shingrix’s crown got off to a promising start after the biopharma’s investigational shingles vaccine held its own against GSK’s mainstay in the first part of a phase 1/2 study.

item.title: FDA agrees to speed review for an ultra-rare disease drug
item.summary: The FDA has agreed to speed up a review of a rare disease drug developed by Stealth BioTherapeutics, a notable step after the company said it may have to close…

item.title: Innovatrix and Opyl Partner to Launch AI-Driven Insurance for Clinical Trial Failure
item.summary: Innovatrix Capital has partnered with Opyl Limited’s TrialKey platform to embed predictive analytics into parametric insurance products designed to cover the financial risk of clinical trial failure. The approach combines risk transfer mechanisms with outcome probability modelling in an attempt to address the heavy capital exposure that accompanies drug development.

item.title: KYORIN Pharmaceutical Adopts AI Drug Discovery Platform From Elix
item.summary: KYORIN Pharmaceutical has adopted Elix Discovery, an AI-based drug discovery platform developed by Tokyo-based Elix. The system is designed to accelerate early-stage research by applying machine learning to compound profiling, molecular generation, and predictive modeling.

item.title: Pharmalittle: We’re reading about Gilead’s HIV drug, FDA speeding review of a rare disease drug, and more
item.summary: CVS Health will not add Gilead Sciences' new HIV prevention drug to its commercial plans for now, despite the medicine's proven effectiveness

item.title: The State of Biotech 2025
item.summary: In GEN’s flagship virtual event, The State of Biotech, outstanding research and business leaders from industry and academia will discuss the latest research developments, innovations, new technologies, and convulsive regulatory changes that are reshaping the world of biotech. The post The State of Biotech 2025 appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Immunai Opens Free Single-Cell Sequencing Program for Academic Labs
item.summary: Immunai, a New York–based company specializing in AI-driven immune system mapping, has announced a program offering academic researchers free access to its single-cell immune profiling platform, covering transcriptomic, surface proteomic, and TCR sequencing for studies of up to 1,000 human samples. The initiative is aimed at groups studying cancer, autoimmunity, and immunotherapy, as well as other immune-related areas, and is intended to offset reduced access to research infrastructure caused by tightening federal funding.

item.title: Gilead’s Kite sails into in vivo CAR-T space with $350M Interius buyout
item.summary: Gilead has become the latest pharma to strengthen its in vivo cell therapy credentials this year, paying $350 million for CAR-T developer Interius BioTherapeutics.

item.title: Generative AI comes up with novel antibiotic structures
item.summary: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed a generative AI model that was able to generate novel antibiotic structures from either chemical fragments or de novo, starting from ammonia, methane, water or no starting point at all. In a study that was published online in Cell, the team tested two dozen of more than 10 million structures that were proposed as potential antibiotics by the model.

item.title: Gilead’s Kite Pharma acquires Interius BioTherapeutics for $350 million
item.summary: Gilead subsidiary Kite Pharma said that it has acquired Interius BioTherapeutics and its single-shot CAR-T program for $350 million.

item.title: FDA accelerates Stealth Bio's rare disease application with a decision slated for next month
item.summary: The FDA has accepted Stealth BioTherapeutics’ third new drug application for its ultrarare disease candidate, providing a planned decision date of Sept. 26.

item.title: Signos adds AI to CGM to drive weight loss
item.summary: Signos Inc. landed U.S. FDA clearance for its over-the-counter glucose monitoring system, which combines Dexcom Inc.'s non-prescription Stelo continuous glucose monitor with an AI-powered platform focused on weight management and metabolism. The sensor transmits glucose readings to a smartphone app that interprets the data, provides guidance for healthy habits and educates the user.

item.title: Andelyn and Amplo Biotechnology Partner to Manufacture Gene Therapies for NMJ Diseases
item.summary: By adopting this Andelyn Biosciences' platform, Amplo Biotechnology aims to advance its AAV gene therapy programs toward clinical evaluation, focusing on the safety and efficacy required for upcoming trials. item.title: Masimo sues US Customs over Apple Watch blood oxygen green light
item.summary: Masimo is taking the U.S. government to court over its decision to allow blood oxygen tracking to return to the Apple Watch, saying its decision was unlawful and that Apple’s workaround still infringes on its sensor patents.

item.title: FDA approves Ionis drug that prevents swelling attacks caused by a rare disease
item.summary: Ionis Pharmaceuticals won FDA approval for a drug that prevents painful swelling attacks triggered by a rare genetic condition, hereditary angioedema.

item.summary: A major U.S. drug manufacturing plant did not properly investigate cat hair, pests, and other problems, the FDA found in a recent inspection report.

item.title: Brain’s Body Map Persists Even After Limb Amputation
item.summary: The brain holds a map of the body that remains unchanged after limb amputation, upending a long-standing belief about brain plasticity. This has implications for treating phantom limb pain and developing artificial limbs controlled by brain-computer interface. item.title: Generative AI comes up with novel antibiotic structures
item.summary: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed a generative AI model that was able to generate novel antibiotic structures from either chemical fragments or de novo, starting from ammonia, methane, water or no starting point at all. In a study that was published online in Cell, the team tested two dozen of more than 10 million structures that were proposed as potential antibiotics by the model.

item.summary: And other health news from the Morning Rounds Friday edition.

item.summary: The Cleveland Clinic's Nathan Pennell, M.D., Ph.D., is switching to the Big Pharma realm to head up hematology and oncology medical affairs at Bristol Myers Squibb.

item.summary: Lighthouse Pharmaceuticals’ plan to become a beacon of hope for Alzheimer’s disease patients has received almost $50 million in U.S. government support.

item.summary: From new hires to departures, promotions and transfers, here are the latest comings and goings in the pharmaceutical industry.

item.summary: Arena BioWorks has laid off 30% of its workers 19 months after launching with $500 million and visions of bringing the Bell Labs model to biotech.

item.title: Supreme Court greenlights $783M in NIH grant cuts tied to Trump's DEI crackdown
item.summary: The Supreme Court is allowing the Trump administration to axe $783 million in federal research funding, reversing a lower court’s decision that required the National Institutes of Health to keep funding the terminated grants.

item.title: Thermo Fisher opens automated lab tools plant in North Carolina
item.summary: The site in Mebane, between Durham and Greensboro, can churn out 96 pipette tips every 12 seconds, as well as 5,000 finished assemblies every hour.

item.title: Amyloid Attenuated by Midkine Protein in Alzheimer’s Mouse Model
item.summary: One of the most correlated proteins with amyloid beta in the proteomic anlaysis of postmortem human brain tissues of Alzheimer’s, midkine is now shown to mitigate amyloid fibril assembly and plaque formation. item.title: Large-Scale Metabolomics Enabled by Anion-Exchange Chromatography Mass Spectrometry
item.summary: A new protocol enables large-scale metabolomics by coupling ion-exchange chromatography with mass spectrometry using electrochemical ion suppression. The new method offers deep coverage of metabolic pathways and potential for unlocking disease insights. The post Large-Scale Metabolomics Enabled by Anion-Exchange Chromatography Mass Spectrometry appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: Tempus claims AI pathology developer Paige in $81M deal
item.summary: Tempus bought the former Fierce 15 winner in part for its spanning nearly 7 million digitized pathology slides and clinical data from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

item.title: Antitumor Immunity May Be Enhanced by Tregs Expressing FOXP3 Variant
item.summary: A preclinical study found that regulatory T cells expressing a shortened form of FOXP3 can promote cytotoxic T cell-mediated antitumor activity. A morpholino oligo that reprograms Treg cells to express the shorter FOXP3 variant boosted antitumor activity in mice. The post Antitumor Immunity May Be Enhanced by Tregs Expressing FOXP3 Variant appeared first on GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

item.title: He was 21 when he programmed MyChart. Now he’s the president of Epic
item.summary: He was 21 when he programmed MyChart — now he’s the president of Epic. STAT sat down with Sumit Rana for a wide-ranging interview.

item.title: FDA says it will publish reports of adverse events tied to drugs on daily basis
item.summary: The FDA said it has begun publishing reports of adverse events concerning drugs on a daily basis, instead of quarterly, as it has in the past.

item.title: HHS moves to strip thousands of federal health workers of union rights
item.summary: HHS has moved to strip thousands of federal health agency employees of their collective bargaining rights, according to a union that called the effort illegal.

item.title: Potential Breakthrough in Cell Reprogramming as OpenAI and Retro Biosciences Report 50x Pluripotency Marker Expression Gains
item.summary: OpenAI and Retro Biosciences have released new findings from a joint effort in AI-driven protein engineering. Using GPT-4b micro, a biology-specialized variant of GPT-4o, the team designed two modified versions of Yamanaka factors, RetroSOX and RetroKLF, that showed over 50-fold increases in pluripotency marker expression and improved DNA repair activity during cell reprogramming.

item.title: Opinion: The future of medicine lies in multifunctional therapies
item.summary: Rather than thinking in terms of single targets or isolated therapeutic classes, we now have the opportunity and imperative to think in terms of combinations.

item.title: Amid cries for retraction, a medical journal reviews a discredited, 24-year-old paper on an antidepressant
item.summary: Amid demand for retraction, a leading medical journal is reviewing a discredited study published in 2001 that touted the benefits of a depression pill for adolescents.

item.title: As MAHA turns 1, a fired-up movement is still figuring out how to fulfill its promises
item.summary: 'That is so brilliant. Why didn’t we think of this before?' As MAHA turns 1, STAT examines the growth of the movement and takes stock of its challenges.

item.summary: Lee Dae-hong founded Aivis Inc. in January 2021 as an AI-powered pathology software company, having led the development of the world’s first commercial under-display fingerprint recognition algorithm that was later incorporated into the Galaxy S10 and Galaxy A series of smartphones of Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd.

item.title: Artificial Photosynthesis Moves Forward with New Molecule
item.summary: A new molecule that can store four charges—two positive and two negative—simultaneously under light irradiation marks an important step toward artificial photosynthesis. The work will contribute to new prospects for a sustainable energy future. item.summary: A person who traveled to El Salvador has been diagnosed with New World screwworm — the first reported U.S. case tied to travel to a country with a current outbreak.

item.title: Andelyn and Tern Therapeutics Partner on Gene Therapy Manufacturing

item.title: LSD can help reduce anxiety, new study finds

item.summary: In this GEN webinar, our expert speakers—Tom Brennan (VP Nuclear Medicine at Marken-UPS Healthcare Precision Logistics) and John Zehner (CEO/President of SpectronRx)—will describe the extraordinary journey of a radiopharmaceutical dose and explore the sophisticated dance of just-in-time manufacturing, real-time GPS and temperature tracking, and the intricate coordination required between production facilities, specialized couriers, and clinical teams. item.title: BioNTech's HER2 ADC beats Roche's Kadcyla in phase 3 breast cancer trial

item.summary: Braveheart Bio has waded into the fight for a heart disease market, paying $65 million upfront for a rival to Bristol Myers Squibb’s Camzyos and Cytokinetics’ aficamten.

item.title: Chutes & Ladders—Merck KGaA lands new R&D chief
item.summary: The German pharma giant has found a new pipeline leader in David Weinreich, M.D., who is joining the company as global head of R&D and chief medical officer for its healthcare unit. Weinreich, who will work out of Merck’s Massachusetts R&D site, was most recently an operating partner and senior advisor at Foresite Labs and Foresite Capital Management.

item.title: StockWatch: Ionis Scores on Phase III Data for Olezarsen
